channel.title: [- Tutorial Request -] - FindColor
channel.description:
I am requesting a tutorial on explaining the FindColor function. I do not know how to use that function yet and i really need too.
There is a surprise for a person who does.
Thanks, Dudeofthed.

item.title: [- Tutorial Request -] - FindColor
item.dc:creator: @Freddy1990 Freddy1990
item.description:
@Freddy1990 wrote:

[quote=“dudeofthed, post:3, topic:77685”]Thanks Freddy. But whenever i enter a FindColor Function like this: if(FindColor(XXXXXX,x,y)) then
MoveMouseSmooth(x,y);

it says i need a variable. That is how a FindColor function work doesn’t it?

OFFTOPIC:
How’s the Scar Divi Project coming along?
Also could you add an improved version of silent mouse in there.

Thanks,
Dudeofthed.[/quote]
Erm, SCAR Divi was released yesterday…
And I can’t just add an improved version of silent mouse, I need to find out if and how it is possible to make one

Read full topic

item.title: [- Tutorial Request -] - FindColor
item.dc:creator: @MuNkY MuNkY
item.description:
@MuNkY wrote:

ok mate, first off the finccolor function requires 4 serperate variables, an area to search in as such. if(FindColor(color,x,y,1,1,500,500)) then - that is the proper use of it.

freddy has explained what it means now ill show u some working code -

program ClickColor;
Var
x, y : integer; // your variables to save you x, y cord’s

Procedure FindAndClick;
begin
if(FindColor(x,y,16777215,1,1,500,500))then
clickmouse(x,y,true)
end;

begin
FindAndClick
end.

hope that helps

Read full topic

item.title: [- Tutorial Request -] - FindColor
item.dc:creator: @Freddy1990 Freddy1990
item.description:
@Freddy1990 wrote:

I don’t always like surprises, lol, but I’ll try to explain it…

FindColor is a function that will find a color in a given search area, it searches by going trough forizontal rows of pixels, so a pixel on the upper row will be found before one on a row below it.

The function itself:
function FindColor(var x, y: Integer; color, xs, ys, xe, ye: Integer): Boolean;

The function returns a boolean, which is True if the entered color is found and False if it is not found.
First, the “var x, y: Integer” part, this returns the coordinates where the color was found, you need to declare 2 variables, for example:
var
xx, yy: Integer;
and put them in there, after the function is exacuted these variables will contain the coordinates.
for color you need to enter the color you want to find, you can get this color using the color picker.
xs and ys are the upperleft coordinates of the searcharea
xe and ye are the lowerright coordinates of the search area
These coordinates can also easilly be obtained using the colorpicker…

When you fill in the function you could for example get:
FindColor(xx, yy, 126842, 125, 130, 450, 200)

Because the function returns a boolean in case it is found, you can for example use it in an if statement to do something if the color is found:
if FindColor(xx, yy, 126842, 125, 130, 450, 200) then
begin
…
end;

I hope that somewhat sums it up for ya

Read full topic
